episodes.description: A History & Synopsis of Scientology Violence Against Those Who Expose Its System of Destruction

episodes.title: Scientology's Bizarre 1996 Orientation Film: Join Scientology or Blow Your Brains Out!
episodes.description:
Mitch Brisker and Jeffrey Augustine discuss Scientology's bizarre 1996 Orientation film which all new members are required to watch. 

After watching the film, new Scientologists must sign a contract stating they have seen the film and agree that Scientology is a religion. 

This is the first of four membership contracts all Scientologists must sign which systematically strip them of their civil and legal rights. 

See Jeffrey Augustine's article on this and read the contracts for yourself: https://scientologymoneyproject.com/2016/12/14/dox-how-scientology-ensnares-the-unsuspecting-in-a-series-of-binding-contracts/

In the 1996 version, the film's narrator declared that you could join Scientology or walk away from it -- and if you chose to walk away you could also jump off a bridge or blow your brains out. 

L. Ron Hubbard scripted the 1996 film when he was alive. Typical of Hubbard's work, he created a false sense of danger in which Scientology or unaliving one's self were the only possible options. 

In this video, Mitch shows a letter written to him by David Miscavige who praised the Orientation film as the greatest film ever made.

episodes.title: From Engrams to Entities: Why L. Ron Hubbard Dumped Freud & Crossed Over to the Dark Side
episodes.description: In this podcast, Jeffrey Augustine traces the hidden reasons why L. Ron Hubbard dumped his Freudian-based Dianetics system and crossed over into the Occult OT Levels to gain money, power, and control over his followers.

episodes.title: Scientology: Lying in the Rain with a Rat Below Your Crotch & Other Weird Things L. Ron Hubbard said
episodes.description:
L. Ron Hubbard wrote and said thousands of strange and weird things and made them all part of official Scientology doctrine. 

Jeffrey Augustine discusses four of these weird things in the first episode of his new series "Weird Things L. Ron Hubbard Said."

episodes.title: Hubbard's Great Fraud: Irrefutable Evidence that L. Ron Hubbard Did Not Create Scientology. 4/5
episodes.description:
Long-time Scientology critic and California PI Jeffrey Augustine reveals the astonishing facts showing how and why L. Ron Hubbard pulled off his "Big Bamboozle" in 1951 to reboot the staggering failure that was Dianetics as it headed towards bankruptcy.  

Augustine shows how L. Ron Hubbard did not invent the e-meter and did not create auditing. Rather, Augustine shows precisely how Hubbard took the work of others to relabel Dianetics as "Scientology."

Erratum: Jeffrey Augustine uses the word "copyright" in this video whereas the correct term is "trademark." Commenters are thanked for pointing this out. A correction will be stated in the next video.

episodes.title: The Psychiatrist Who Used an E-Meter in 1906: The Real Truth About the Creation of "Scientology" 3/5
episodes.description:
Long-time Scientology critic and California PI Jeffrey Augustine discusses the history of the galvanometer and how it came to be used in psychiatric research in the 19th century. 

Augustine presents the facts of how the legendary Swiss psychotherapist Carl Jung used the meter in his formal psychiatric research in 1906. Jung's work with the e-meter and word association was published in English in 1919.  Click over to the Scientology Money Project to read Jung's 1919 "Studies in Word Association": 

Augustine's central point in this video is that Psychiatry was using the e-meter in psychotherapy decades before L. Ron Hubbard adopted the work of a psychotherapy researcher and inventor and called it Scientology.  

Sorry Scientologists: The Psychs were doing auditing with a meter long before L. Ron Hubbard was even born.

episodes.title: Narcotics, Hypnosis & Past Lives: The Real Truth About the Creation of Scientology - Part 2 of 5
episodes.description:
Scientology Money Project author Jeffrey Augustine introduces his three-part series which presents the evidence showing why L. Ron Hubbard was not the actual creator of Scientology. 

In this video Augustine shows Hubbard's use of narcotics and hypnosis in his pre-Dianetics days. He also discusses how past lives in Dianetics became a public relations problem for L. Ron Hubbard.

Augustine shows the story arc of Dianetics: An overnight sensation followed two years later by bankruptcy. Why did Dianetics implode and crash in only two years?

episodes.title: Black Magick:  The Real Truth About the Creation of Scientology - Part 1 of 5
episodes.description:
Scientology Money Project author Jeffrey Augustine introduces his three-part series which presents the evidence showing why L. Ron Hubbard was not the actual creator of Scientology. 

Augustine answers one question he has been asked many times: Did L. Ron Hubbard practice Black Magick?

In Part 1 Augustine offers a brief overview of the influences on L. Ron Hubbard prior to the release of Dianetics on May 9, 1950. These influences include Hubbard's near death experience in 1937; the US Navy; Sigmund Freud; Aleister Crowley; Jack Parsons; Goetia; and Hubbard's early career as a pulp fiction writer. 


L. Ron Hubbard's Affirmations (scroll down to bottom of page): https://scientologymoneyproject.com/2023/03/03/proof-that-l-ron-hubbard-did-not-create-scientology-the-prelude-part-1/

The Scientology Money Project: https://scientologymoneyproject.com/

Surviving Scientology Channel on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/@SurvivingScientology
